description.narrative:
Insatsen School Improvement Fund (SIF) är en givar- och myndighetsgemensam fond för förvaltningsmedel till skolor i Kambodja. Medel från fonden distribueras till alla offentliga skolor från förskola till och med sekundärskolan. Denna fond ersätter den tidigare svenskfinansierade fonden School Improvement Grants (SIG) och den statliga School Operational Budget (SOB).
Det kambodjanska finansministeriet, Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF), är Sidas avtalspartner som representant för den kambodjanska regeringen och mottagare av det svenska bidraget. De svenska medlen överförs från MEF (från ett specifikt bankkonto för Sidas bidrag) till det kambodjanska utbildningsministeriet, Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports (MoEYS). Förmedling till skolorna av SIF-programmets medel sker genom banktransfereringar från MoEYS. Avtalet klargör att MoEYS är ansvarigt ministerium för genomförande av programmet och Sidas huvudsakliga motpart i genomförandet.
Framsteg har skett inom utbildningssektorn i Kambodja under det senaste årtiondet, särskilt på låg- och mellanstadienivå. Ett antal system- och ledningsrelaterade svagheter kvarstår dock. Vidare är utbildningskvaliteten låg och alltför få barn fullföljer skolan bortom de första sju skolåren. För att bistå i att hantera några av dessa utmaningar beslutade Sida i september 2013 att lämna stöd till en utbyggnad av ett system för flexibla skolbidrag genom SIG-programmet.
En uttalad ambition för insatsen var att de lärdomar som genererades inom SIG-programmet skulle påverka det existerande statliga transfereringssystemet för förvaltningsbidrag till skolorna (SOB) genom att SIG och SOB skulle slås samman inom ramen för ett enhetligt, effektivt och flexibelt system för överföring och hantering av delegerade skolbidrag. Avsikten med Sidas stöd till SIG var således också att uppnå en systemeffekt. För att minska riskerna med en omfattande kontanthantering i flera led inom utbildningssystemet, ställde Sida som krav att bankkonton skulle öppnas för skolorna för att möjliggöra direkttransfereringar från central nivå till de enskilda skolorna. Hantering av formella finansiella flöden sker nu via banksystemet för alla offentliga skolor.
Enligt den studie av offentliga finansiella flöden inom utbildningsystemet (Public Expenditure Tracking Survey – PETS) som har genomförts av Världsbanken under 2017 har användningen av banktransfereringar i sig lett till en stor förändring för att minska felaktig användning av medel. Den PETS som genomfördes av Världsbanken 2006 fann att endast 70 % av förvaltningsbidragen kom fram till skolorna, PETS 2017 finner att 100 % av medlen nu kommer fram. PETS 2017, liksom andra rapporter, konstaterar vidare att den kvalitetshöjning som skett på lokal skolnivå kan härledas direkt från SIG systemet på grund av dess fokus på lokala behov och förutsättningar.
Det nya systemet för förvaltningsbidrag till skolor, SIF, bygger på erfarenhet från såväl SOB som SIG. Den största skillnaden mot SIG-programmet är att Kambodja och Sverige åtar sig att gemensamt finansiera insatsen. SIG-programmet var inledningsvis endast finansierat av Sverige men på grund av växelkursförändringar och svenska kronans sjunkande värde under genomförandetiden bidrog det kambodjanska finansministeriet med medel motsvarande underskottet i den planerade budgeten. Regler och instruktioner för de lokala skolornas användning och rapportering av medlen i SIF programmet är i stort sett samstämmiga med reglerna och instruktionerna för SIG-programmet.
Genom SIF kommer bidrag att nå ut till samtliga ca 8 900 offentliga skolor från grundskola till gymnasium (fler än 11 000 enheter, när de förskolor som finns inom vissa primärskolor räknas in). SIF:s förvaltningsbidrag, i motsats till det tidigare SOB systemet, innebär att skolorna har långtgående befogenheter att bestämma över hur delegerade medel ska användas. Användningen av SIF-medlen regleras i en instruktion fastställd av MoEYS; i huvudsak får medlen användas för ökad undervisningskvalitéet, mindre underhåll av lokaler samt stöd till svaga elever. Härigenom ökar möjligheterna att tillfredsställa de faktiska behov som finns i skolorna, vilket i sin tur på sikt förväntas bidra till förbättrad utbildningskvalitet och minskade avhopp.
På grund av den negativa politiska utvecklingen i Kambodja under 2017 har Sida beslutat att tills vidare inte ingå nya insatsavtal inom utvecklingssamarbetet som innebär att det kanaliseras finansiella resurser direkt till staten, med undantag för stöd till utbildning och forskning. Fortsatt stöd till decentraliseringsreformen kommer därmed inte att utgå. Ökad kunskap och höjd utbildningsnivå bedöms långsiktigt vara förutsättning för ett hållbart demokratiskt samhälle i Kambodja. De senaste decenniernas stora framsteg för ökad tillgång till grundutbildning och en långsam kvalitetshöjning inom utbildningsystemet, samt den kraftiga ökningen av antalet studerande på högskolenivå bedöms ha bidragit till den snabba ekonomiska utvecklingen som landet åtnjuter och de ökade kraven som framställs på medborgarinflytande och yttrandefrihet. Fortsatt och långsiktigt stöd till utbildning och forskning bedöms vara ett viktigt bidrag till en långsiktig demokratisk utveckling.
Mot bakgrund av ovanstående föreslås att Sida lämnar stöd till insatsen School Improvement Fund för åren 2018-2021, med ett totalbelopp om 186 500 000 kronor. Av medlen kommer Sida att behålla 6 500 000 kronor för uppföljningskomponenten medan resterande 180 000 000 kronor utbetalas direkt till det kambodjanska finansministeriet (MEF).

The intervention School Improvement Fund is jointly funded by external development partners and the Government of Cambodia and provides operational funding to all public schools in Cambodia from pre-school to upper-secondary level. This fund replaces the Swedish funded School Improvement Grants (SIG) as well as the Government budget item School Operational Budget (SOB)

The objective of the programme is to support MoEYS in establishing a sustainable School Improvement Fund (SIF) that will support improved completion and graduation rates of students in early childhood education, primary, lower secondary and upper secondary levels, with enhanced gender parity at all levels. In order to achieve this objective SIDA will support the co-financing of the SIF between 2018 and 2021. This co-financing will incrementally decrease each year in order to assist Royal Government of Cambodia in incrementally graduating towards full financing of the SIF by 2022. In addition, SIDA will provide complementary funding to assist the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sports (MoEYS) in conducting evidence-based impact monitoring, technical reviews and programme evaluation. Broader capacity building support to the establishment of the new SIF will be provided through the MoEYS Capacity Development Partnership Fund (CDPF). The expected outcome objectives of the interevention are: (1) expanded access to education services at pre-school, primary and secondary levels; (2) improved completion rates for primary, lower and upper secondary levels; and (3) improved capacity for school management.

participating-org.narrative: Ministry of Economy and Finance, Phnom Pehn

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.

description.narrative: The overall objective of the intervention was to support Cambodia in providing and assuring more equitable provision of quality education services. To reach this overall objective and the three outcome objectives stated above, the intervention specifically aimed at expanding access to education services to reach the most vulnerable groups of children; addressing education quality and relevance through purchase of learning materials and other activities; addressing efficiency issues by enabling greater survival and completion of students in the pre-primary and school-based education system; and building capacity for school management, including financial planning and follow up. The theory of change behind the expected outcome objectives was based on the assumption that low attendance levels and high drop-out rates were an interaction between supply and demand-side factors. Supply-side factors are linked to the school context and relate both to structural problems, such as teacher shortages and poor educational relevance and quality, and to a lack of facilities such as water and working latrines. Some of these factors can be addressed by interventions focused on the school level. Demand-side factors are those embedded in the home and community and relate to factors that reduce the demand for education. This includes attitudinal factors, distance to school and economic considerations. The flexible nature of the grants has enabled the schools to identify and address the most pressing needs, as perceived by both school administrators and parents, and this has positively influenced both supply-side and demand-side constraints. Based on what is stated above, it is concluded that there is a logic link between the objective at overall level, the outcome objectives and the component objectives, and that these are supported by relevant activities as well as by a reasonably robust theory of change. Sida provided support to the School Improvement Grant (SIG) from 2013 to 2017 as a standalone system parallel to the Government School Operational Budget (SOB) system. One of the outcomes of the SIG was that budget distributed through the SOB increased considerably as increased funding directly to schools showed considerable positive results. Another outcome was that the Ministry of Economy and Finance together with the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport approached Sida for a continued funding but through a joint system, School Improvement Fund (later changed to School Operational Fund), based on the formulas and structure of SIG. Contrary to the SIG the SIF/SOF mechanism channelled Sida and the Cambodian Governments funding to schools. Other development partners channelled also their respective funding to schools through the SIF/SOF mechanism, these were World Bank, ADB, UNICEF and World Food Program. In addition to this joint funding mechanism of official funding other sources of funding, from the local communities and others, have become integrated sources of the local budget giving schools stable budget planning horizon. Key progress has been observed in school administration and the capacity to plan quality school improvement and financial management, through the basic and secondary cycles from early childhood education to secondary schools. At the school level, strengthening school management (including the preparation of annual operational plans), implementation of the budget plan with an effective fund using, developing school report and present to the public. Part of this are regular meetings with the local community, to encourage the participation in school activities and to identify the risk of dropout and encouraging parents and care takers to monitor teacher performance. The result has been increased engagement and participation from parents and the local community including in maintaining school facilities. The risk of dropout rate has been reduced, the actual figures show that 55.8% of students at lower secondary level and 38.7% of students at upper secondary levels finish respective cycle compared to expected outcomes in the programme document of 43.1% and 24.7%, respectively. The District Offices of Education (DOE) have played an important role in guiding and supporting schools at primary level in the use of the SIF/SOF funds, The Province Offices of Education (POE) have had the same role vis-à-vis the secondary level. At the central level, several departments and entities such as the SIF/SOF secretariat, Early Childhood Education Department, Primary Education Department, Department of Planning, Monitoring and Evaluation Department, Department of Finance, and Internal Audit Department participated in supporting, monitoring and coordinating on SIF/SOF Administration and Finance Programme Management at school levels. The period 2018 2021 in the development of the education system as such and particularly the schools is sharply divided into two areas, before and during the Covid-19 pandemic. Prior to the pandemic the education was slowly moving in the right direction with increased learning outcomes. Due to the pandemic all education institutions in Cambodia were closed from mid-March until beginning of December 2020 and again from February util the end of the activity period of the intervention on 30 June 2021. Not only were the schools closed but gathering of people in general was severely restricted. MoEYS was partially able to respond to the negative impact of COVID-19 on education system during the pandemic. Centrally as well as at local level intensive activities were undertaken to establish and conduct distance learning, both though the use of digital media and through the distribution of printed material for self-study. Teachers and schools developed flexible way of providing education. It is however clear that this has had a very serious negative impact on student learning. The Narrative report summarises findings at aggregated level but does not give any detailed overview of the outcomes at school level. The sudden turn to digital and distance learning was very challenging for the system and especially for students. This also exposed the huge difference in access to digital tools and other support between the poorer and vulnerable majority of the population and the well-of minority. This can be seen in the figures reported by the MoEYS: Only 7. 71 % of teachers at basic level (grades 1-9) could use using Zoom or Google Meet (the preferred distance tools): 67. 76% could be reached by Telegram or Messenger including access to educational videos, but 22.56% could provide teaching delivered to small groups of students. Only 3.87% of students at basic level (grades 1-9) could use Zoom or Google Meet to study, and 12.34% reported that they had been studying with teachers in small groups. According to MoEYS report more than 49% of students at this level did not participate in distance learning Only 21% of students at secondary level (grades 10-12) used digital media to study and 19% could make use of the extra text material and worksheets provided. According to MoEYS report more than 50% of the students at this level did not participate in distance learning. According to MoEYS the main reason for this low uptake of digital distance learning was that most students were not able to access the internet because of lack of technical access (smartphone, table or computer). Parts of the Sida supported Quality and Inclusive programme implemented by UNICEF (PlanIT ID 13639) were reallocated in agreement with Sida to address learning loss due to the school closure. With this reallocated budget and specific EU support in addition to the SIF/SOF funds, schools were able to procure and prepare materials to address the challenges of distance learning, although the process was slow due to restrictions of travel and physical gatherings to prevent the spread of the Covid virus. Due to this critical disruption and learning loss during the last one and a half year of the implementation of the intervention the indicators presented in the project document were not fully achieved.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
